alert.note: Alert for Crawford; Grant; Richland (Wisconsin) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS LaCrosse (Southwestern Wisconsin, Southeastern Minnesota, and Northeast Iowa)
info.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued February 21 at 12:38PM CST until February 23 at 6:00PM CST by NWS LaCrosse
info.description: ...Snow Is Moving Toward The Area This Afternoon... .At 1220 pm, radar indicated snow across much of western into southcentral Minnesota, heading steadily east. Visibilities are below one mile in some spots within the snow, and accumulations occurred rapidly after the snow began. The snow is forecast to spread in from west to east this afternoon. A band of 5 to 8 inches of snow is still expected north of Interstate 90 through the I-94 corridor. Snow amounts will decrease very quickly south of I-90. Blowing and drifting snow Wednesday morning is expected as winds increase. The second and stronger wave of snow arrives from south to north Wednesday across the entire area. By the time the storm ends late Thursday, an additional 8 to 12 inches of snow is expected northwest of an Austin, Minnesota to Necedah, Wisconsin line. sleet and freezing rain are a expected south of this line. Ice amounts over a quarter of an inch are possible along and south of the Highway 18 corridor between Wednesday evening and Thursday morning with the risk of tree and power line damage amplified by winds gusting to 30 to 40 mph. This will be a HIGHLY impactful winter storm with travel severely impacted at times. ...WINTER STORM WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH THURSDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Heavy mixed precipitation possible. Total snow and sleet accumulations of 1 inch in Highway 18 and south, and 2 to 5 inches north of Highway 18. Ice accumulations of around three tenths of an inch possible, mainly south of Highway 18, Winds could gust as high as 40 mph. * WHERE...Portions of north central and northeast Iowa and southwest Wisconsin. * WHEN...From Wednesday through Thursday afternoon. * IMPACTS...Power outages and tree damage are likely due to the ice. Travel could be nearly impossible. Patchy blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute.
info.instruction: Monitor the latest forecasts for updates on this situation.
